description: Number of different primes that can be formed by permuting digits of n-th prime.
comments: Leading zeros not permitted, so, e.g., prime(27) = 103 but a(27) = 1 even though 13 and 31 are both primes. - _Harvey P. Dale_, Dec 17 2012
example: a(75)=4 because the digits in 379 may be arranged to form a total of 4 primes: 379, 397, 739 and 937.
mathematica: ndp[n_]:=Module[{pers=FromDigits/@Permutations[IntegerDigits[n]]}, Count[ pers,_?(IntegerLength[#]==IntegerLength[n]&&PrimeQ[#]&)]]; ndp/@ Prime[ Range[110]] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Dec 17 2012 *)
author: _Enoch Haga_, Mar 16 2000
